p: Fall re-initiation of plant growth declined by 67.8% over our study, which correlated with increasing summer temperature, i.e., greater summer senescence. Fall plant production now is very low in most years, as it may be more difficult for plants to overcome severe summer senescence. This differs from the historic pattern of fall “greening” in this ecosystem [ 33]. For example, in 1805, Lewis and Clark mentioned this [ 79], and 19 th and early 20 th century settlers [ 80– 82] relied on this to provide livestock forage after summer senescence.
